The economic news out of South Africa is unremittingly bad: 25% unemployment, less than 1% expected GDP growth for 2016, public debt as a percentage of GDP nearing 50%, a 10% drop in the rand's value since December, etc.[1]. The current South African Finance Minister, Pravin Gordhan, has gone so far as to describe his country as being in a "crisis"[2]. However, "Moody's Investor Service said on Wednesday Finance Minister Pravin Gordhan's planned tax increases in his 2016 Budget Speech were well targeted, given the weak economic backdrop"[3]. Clearly, Moody's is not jumping for joy about the situation in South Africa: "South Africa's budget aims to quickly consolidate spending by cutting a large public sector wage bill, but has not identified specific revenue measures to achieve smaller deficits, Moody's said on Wednesday"[4], and it seems very hard to avoid the conclusion that Moody's will downgrade South Africa at least one level. But a 4 level drop doesn't seem to be in the cards, as far as I can see.

Moody's currently estimates the probability of South Africa's credit rating moving from a Baa2 to a rating of B or lower within 1 year to be ~6%. A two month forecast would place the probability at close to 1% if assuming that the likelihood is linearly dependent on time. Yet, South Africa's approaching elections (in May) mean that Zuma may enact reforms beforehand in an effort to appease disgruntled citizens which could have the effect of negatively impacting the economy. Therefore, I place my forecast a little higher (at 4%).

Moodys estimates that the probability of moving from a Baa2 (SAs current rating) to a rating of B or lower within 1 year to be ~6%. I adjust this downwards to reflect the lower likelihood of default in the next two months vs. the one year. The problem with this estimate is twofold. One, is that this is an estimate that is probably to focused on more developed countries (US/EU) and does not take into account the very country specific problems that South Africa is facing. The second problem is the timing. Moody's does not have an estimate for 2 months out readily available, so I make the assumption that the likelihood of downgrade  increases with time linearly (they are more likely to get downgraded the further out in time we go), this is probably an oversimplification as the decrease in probability is most certainly not linearly based, but for purposes of simplicity this is what I have done.

South Africa will be downgraded but not to B and not by April 1st. Moody's announces Sovereign rating reviews according to an annual calendar that they release every year. South Africa is on the April, August, December cycle so there is no rating announcement due prior to April 1st. The only reason for an announcement ahead of schedule would be in the event of a default. South Africa doesn't have a bond maturing before April 1st so they can't default on a Principal payment. In theory there could be a default on coupon payments but that is typically only seen in very extreme cases and is a long way from where South Africa is today. Default probability before April 1st is approx 1%

Determinants of sovereign ratings include GDP growth, per capita income, inflation, fiscal balance, external balance, external debt and level of economic development. GDP growth for the 2014 - 2015 fiscal year has been rather paltry (0.78). It's forecasted rate for both middle income countries and as a BRICs member is expected to decline further for the 2015 - 2016 fiscal year. A significant effect on currency devaluation is external debt and external balance. The decline of growth among BRICs nations also has a significant effect of global growth in the global economy. Additionally, a sharp decline in commodity prices weaken trade balances, affecting external debt and external balances. Therefore, a relatively low rate of economic growth suggests that a country’s existing debt burden will become more problematic to service over time. Foreign indebtedness may become unsustainable over time.
